text:
hey everyone welcome to Pai's kitchen so a couple 
weeks ago I showed you how to make the soft Asian

style fluffy buns today I'm gonna take that base 
dough and show you what else you can do with it so

I am making what's commonly called Mexican coffee 
buns or just coffee buttons and what it is it's

fluffy dough with a coffee flavored cookie crust 
on top with butter that's stuffed in the middle

and it melts into the dough yes it is as good as 
it sounds now this is super popular in Southeast

Asia you might know it by the name of rotiboy 
or Papa roti in Thailand it's mr. buns and all

these like male bun brands I don't know why that 
is but it's super easy actually to make at home

especially once you've got the dough made so 
let's get started so what I've got here is my

basic fluffy white bread dough that I made and I 
made it last night I let it proof in the fridge

overnight I've let it sit out now for about an 
hour 2 hours until it's no longer hard and now

we're gonna move on from here and of course you 
don't have to do it overnight you can just do

it all in one go and it'll just take one hour to 
proof at room temperature so I'm gonna turn this

whole thing out onto my board here press out 
all the gas from the dough you want to split

this dough into two portions the first portion is 
gonna be a hundred and eighty grams so you want a

scale handy I mean if you don't have a scale you 
can kind of estimate but it just makes everything

so much easier when you do have a scale all right 
so we'll leave that to one side for now and this

small amount of dough is actually going to be 
our butter protector so the buns have salted

butter as a filling and I find that if you just 
wrap the butter and in the bun just one layer the

butter likes to leak out when you bake it but 
if you wrap it twice it doesn't leak as much

so I'm gonna divide this into 12 equal portions 
because that's how many buns I am making 16 grams

oh that's pretty good if you guys 15/16 yurga so 
I've got here some I'm sorry Soltis butter I'm so

used to cooking with unsalted butter but this is 
when you want to cook with salted butter because

that saltiness is gonna mix with the sweetness of 
the buns it's gonna be so good and now what I'll

do is they'll take one of these and then I'll 
take this which is actually a pestle a little

wooden pestle that I have you can use a rolling 
pin or whatever rod shaped objects you have and

just roll this out into a sheet okay now you take 
one piece of butter put it in and you just wrap it

now you want to make sure you seal it really well 
again if you don't the butter will leak out while

you bake make sure you really pinch it pinch 
it and now I'm gonna put this seam side down

and you'll see why in a minute so now I've got my 
little army of dough protected butter I'm moving

on to the outer bun so the rest of this now then 
I divide that also into 12 equal pieces and by the

way I don't actually know if this recipe came from 
Mexico and that's why they call it Mexican coffee

bun if you're Mexican and you know let me know in 
the comments now with this this is your outside

bun so it has to look good so what I do is I first 
sort of flatten it and then bring it together in

the center so that this way you get a relatively 
smooth ish side okay doesn't have to be perfect

at this point and then we do the same thing as we 
did in my sort of plain bun video where you drag

it to create a taut surface like that well come 
to think of it in this recipe it really doesn't

matter who's gonna put a cookie crust on top 
but anyway and then you put it up this way and

roll it out now you put your butter bun seam side 
down okay this is very important seam site down

and then you wrap the big dough around the little 
dough and now you'll notice that this is now the

bottom of the bun twist it pinch it make sure it's 
really well sealed I mean if it does leak it's not

a huge deal I always get a couple of leaks but 
it's just better if it doesn't right so now you

flip this up and you'll notice that the the theme 
of the butter is now up so if the but if your

butter seam is not as well sealed it's at least 
facing upward rice is containing the butter like

in a little bowl so that's why you kind of have 
to keep track of where your seams are and where

you put it and all that Jess and that there's 
a little button how cute is that I'm gonna just

lay these out onto a parchment-lined sheet here 
if you don't have parchment you can just grease

your pan but you definitely want to make sure 
it's greased because otherwise these will stick

these will need to proof again so they'll about 
double in size at room temperature for about one

hour if it's colder where you live it's gonna 
take a little longer okay make sure you cover

it with a towel or plastic wrap so they don't 
dry out ooh and that's it so while these are

rising I am going to make the cookie crust so 
the cookie crust is super easy what I've got

here is unsalted butter that I have left to sit 
at room temperature and just to make sure it's

really nice and soft I just like to go and whizz 
it up a little there we go it's nice and soft now

to this I'm going to add some powdered sugar 
or icing sugar or confectioners sugar however

you call it in different parts of the world and 
be careful because this part if you turn your

machine too quickly too fast it'll just you just 
inhale a bunch of sugar so low speed to start

okay and now you notice that it's actually really 
nice and light and fluffy now I'm gonna add my

eggs so I've just got one at a time for now I'm 
going in with my second egg okay so that's good

enough for now so I'm gonna just take a break 
from this for a second and look at our coffee

component of this making sure this doesn't fall 
over stay good stuff all right so the coffee so

I've got here instant coffee because you can get 
a lot of coffee flavor without excess liquid so

you don't want too much water in this cookie 
dough right otherwise it's really runny so but

it does need a little bit of liquid to help 
it dissolve so I've just got here some water

and this is well it was hot water anyway now it's 
just kind of warm but it will just help dissolve

and if the water was actually hot it would be a 
lot easier so to help this long I'm also gonna

add my vanilla into here now while we're here I 
might as well get my dry ingredients mixed up so

I've got in here just some all-purpose flour and 
then I'm gonna have some baking powder and salt

into here and use a mini whisk to get that all 
mixed up now I'm gonna put everything together

so back with the butter bowl coffee mixture 
goes right in ooh dark and intense then you

can add more coffee or if you don't want coffee 
at all you just want a vanilla that's fine as well

and now I know it looks all gross and 
curdled that's because you've got fat

and you've got water and they don't want to 
mix right that's okay do not panic that's

when we add the flour mixture and that'll 
help bring everything together but if your

butter is cold even after you add the flour 
sometimes it still remains curdle so that's

why it's important that your ingredients are at 
room temperature low speed to get this mixed up

now you don't want to get your beaters to clean 
cuz you're gonna want to lick this stuff off it's

so good mmm not too much so it got you sick but 
a little bit a little bit so good and that is

it that's such an easy cookie topping and now 
I need to put this in a piping bag if you don't

have a piping bag that's okay then all you need is 
a ziplock bag like this okay so I'm just gonna put

all of this stuff in here and by the way folding 
the top just helps prevent the the top part from

getting all dirty and stuff this is something 
you know in Thailand they sell curries and food

in plastic bags and they always fold the top and 
it just makes it easier to keep the bag open - now

this will be more than you need for your buns but 
I always like to make sure there's a little bit

extra it's better than not having enough right but 
if you have extra you can just pipe it out onto

a baking sheet and actually bake it into a cookie 
don't seal this all the way just yet cuz you want

to squeeze all the air out and try to get this to 
the bottom part of the bag look at my buns they

have risen beautifully though rice even a little 
bit more once they're in the oven and now we got

to put the best part on it which is the cookie and 
this is sort of similar to pineapple bun except

in pineapple buns the cookie toppings a little 
firmer so it doesn't melt to coat the whole thing

and it becomes a little bit cracked on the top but 
it's the same concept so now with this turn into

a piping bag you got to cut a little hole just 
one word of advice is don't make it too too big

you can always cut more if it's too small but if 
you cut it too big game over right and it always

looks smaller than it actually is there we go and 
easy-peasy it doesn't have to be perfect because

these will melt down anyway so if there's a hole 
somewhere you can just go back and fix it like if

I wanted to I can feel that and if your buns are 
not perfectly circular and you have to go and add

to one side of it that's totally totally fine 
just do what you got to do and a tip for piping

is always push this down your your thumb and your 
index finger should always be pushing everything

down it gets really hard when all of this it's 
like a toothpaste right if all of this stuff is

all over the bag then you have you're able to 
apply less pressure and now I'm just looking to

see for if there's like a side that's jetting 
out that doesn't have as much cookie on top so

I go and add that in now you're just gonna bake 
these for about 15 minutes in a 375 degree oven

look at these buds look how good they look and

I'm talking to you my Southeast Asian brothers and 
sisters you know the stuff is good right oh by the

way this is really important because this crispy 
cookie crust is sitting on top of this moist dough

eventually it'll absorb the moisture from the 
bread and soften it it won't meet crispy anymore

before you serve it if it has gotten soft stick 
it in the oven for just five minutes to dry it off

and crisp it back up that texture makes a world of 
difference so the recipe as always will be on Pais
